sen.j: 懿徳天皇（いとくてんのう、綏靖天皇29年（紀元前553年）- 懿徳天皇34年9月8日 (旧暦)（紀元前477年10月6日））は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に記される第4代の天皇（在位：懿徳天皇元年2月4日 (旧暦)（紀元前510年3月15日） - 同34年9月8日 (旧暦)（紀元前477年10月6日））。
sen.e: Emperor Itoku (A.D. 553-October 1, A.D.477) was the fourth Emperor, who described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (Reign: March 9, A.D.510- October 1, A.D.477).

Emperor Itoku (553 B.C. - October 1, 477 B.C.) was the fourth emperor (reign: March 9, 510 B.C.- October 1, 477 B.C.), being described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Emperor Itoku (553 B.C. - October 1, 477 B.C.) was the fourth emperor (reign: March 9, 510 B.C.- October 1, 477 B.C.), being described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 大日本彦耜友尊（おおやまとひこすきとものみこと）・大倭日子鉏友命（『古事記』）。
sen.e: In "kojiki", he was called Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto or Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto.
In kojiki, he is called Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto or Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto.
In kojiki, he is called Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto or Oyamatohikosukitomo no mikoto.

sen.j: いわゆる欠史八代の一人で、実在しない天皇と捉える見方が一般的である（実在説もある）。
sen.e: He was one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns), and it is commonly understood that he was the nonexistent Emperor (There is also the theory of his real existence).
It is commonly understood that he was one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns) to be a nonexistent emperor (the theory of his existence is also present).
It is commonly understood that he was one of the so called Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns) to be a nonexistent emperor (the theory of his existence is also present).
Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace
Imperial Palace

sen.j: 都は軽曲峡宮（かるのまがりおのみや。
sen.e: Its capital was in Karunomagarinomiya.
The capital was in Karunomagarinomiya.
The capital was in Karunomagarinomiya.

sen.j: 現在の奈良県橿原市見瀬町・白橿町か）。
sen.e: (It is considered to be present Mise Town ・Shirakashi cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture)
(It is considered to be possibly present Mise Town ・Shirakashi cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.)
(It is considered to be possibly present Mise Town or Shirakashi cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.)

sen.j: ただし、『古事記』には「軽之境岡宮（かるのさかいおかのみや）」とある。
sen.e: However, there is a description that "the capital was established in Karunosakaiokanomiya" in "Kojiki".
However, there is a description that "the capital was established in Karunosakaiokanomiya" in Kojiki.
However, there is a description that "the capital was established in Karunosakaiokanomiya" in Kojiki.

sen.j: 特に記録されていない。
sen.e: There is no particular description about his achievement.
There is no particular description about his achievement.
There is no particular description about his achievement.

sen.j: 安寧天皇11年（紀元前538年）1月に立太子。
sen.e: In February, A.D. 538, he was formally installed as Crown Prince.
In February, 538 B.C., he was formally installed as Crown Prince.
In February, 538 B.C., he was formally installed as Crown Prince.

sen.j: 懿徳天皇元年（紀元前510年）2月に即位。
sen.e: In March, A.D. 510, he ascended the throne.
In March, 510 B.C., he ascended the throne.
In March, 510 B.C., he ascended the throne.
He died in the 34th year of his reign.
He died in the 34th year of his reign.
He died in the 34th year of his reign.
According to "Nihonshoki", he died at the age of 77, while according to "Kojiki", he died at the age of 45.
According to Nihonshoki, he died at the age of 77, while according to Kojiki, he died at the age of 45.
According to Nihonshoki, he died at the age of 77, while according to Kojiki, he died at the age of 45.

sen.j: なお、中世の『古今和歌集序聞書三流抄』には、天皇が出雲国に行幸して、素戔嗚尊に出会うという逸話が見える。
sen.e: In "Kokin Wakashu Jomonsho Sanryu-sho" (Excerpts from "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry "and explanatory notes) in the Medieval Period, there is an anecdote that Emperor Itoku visited Izumo County and met SUSANO no Mikoto (a deity of Japanese Mythology).

In "Kokin Wakashu Jomonsho Sanryu-sho" (Excerpts from "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry "and explanatory notes) in the Medieval Period, there is an anecdote that Emperor Itoku visited Izumo County and met SUSANO no Mikoto (a deity of Japanese Mythology).

In "Kokin Wakashu Jomonsho Sanryu-sho" (Excerpts from "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry "and explanatory notes) in the Medieval Period, there is an anecdote that Emperor Itoku visited Izumo County and met SUSANO no Mikoto (a deity of Japanese Mythology).
Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum)
Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum)
Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum)

sen.j: 畝傍山南繊沙渓上陵（うねびやまのみなみのまさごたにのえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: Emperor Itoku was buried in Unebiyama no minami no masagotani no e no misasagi (the Unebiyama-no-minami-no-masagotani-no-e Mausoleum).
Emperor Itoku was buried in Unebiyama no minami no masagotani no e no misasagi (the Unebiyama-no-minami-no-masagotani-no-e Mausoleum).
Emperor Itoku was buried in Unebiyama no minami no masagotani no e no misasagi (the Unebiyama-no-minami-no-masagotani-no-e Mausoleum).

sen.j: 『古事記』に「畝傍山の真名子（まなご）谷の上」。
sen.e: In "kojiki", there is a description that "his Misasagi is on Unebiyama no managodani no e (the upper valley of Manago at Mount Unebi)."
In kojiki, there is a description that "his Misasagi is on Unebiyama no managodani no e (upper portion of the valley of Manago at Mount Unebi)."
sen.cmt: Kojikiの引用符を除去。「谷の上」をupper portion of the valleyと訳出し。
sen.e: In kojiki, there is a description that "his Misasagi is on Unebiyama no managodani no e (upper portion of the valley of Manago at Mount Unebi)."

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県橿原市西池尻町に所在する俗称「マナゴ山」（山形墳）に比定されている。
sen.e: Currently, this Misasagi is identified with a familiar name "Manago yama(mountain shaped barrow), that is located in Nishiikejiri-cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Currently, this Misasagi is identified with a familiar name "Manago yama" (mountain-shaped barrow), that is located in Nishiikejiri-cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Minago yamaの右に引用符を追加
sen.e: Currently, this Misasagi is identified with a familiar name "Manago yama" (mountain-shaped barrow), that is located in Nishiikejiri-cho, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 同市畝傍町のイトクノモリ古墳はその名から懿徳陵とされることもあったが、一説に皇后陵だともいわれる。
sen.e: Although Itokunomori-kofun Tomb in Unebi-cho Kashihara City used to be considered as Emperor Itoku's Mausoleum because of its name, there is another theory that this misasagi is for the Empress.
Although Itokunomori-kofun Tomb in Unebi-cho Kashihara City used to be considered as Emperor Itoku's Mausoleum because of its name, there is another theory that this misasagi is for the Empress.
Although Itokunomori-kofun Tomb in Unebi-cho Kashihara City used to be considered as Emperor Itoku's Mausoleum because of its name, there is another theory that this misasagi is for the Empress.
